comments:

(In reply to comment #1)
> Moving to jst.j2ee.
> 

If the WebContent/WEB-INF/lib is created and the six jars are copied to this directory after the project is checked out from CVS, a Web Service can be created.  Initially, the WebContent directory does not exist.  Selecting the server (in this case Tomcat5.5) and starting it creates the WebContent directory.

Carl,

The problem seems to be due to empty folder (WebContent) not checked into CVS and thus not there when the project is checked out.  Is there an option in CVS to check in empty folder?

Also, which WTP driver are you using and what is the exact steps to reproduce the problem.

By CC:  John, could we expect WebContent directory to always be there for dynamic Web project?  If so, then this is a general problem for checking in and out dynamic Web project created using WTP.

If not, then we would need to fool-proof our code to not expect the directory to be there and create it if necessary.

Anyway, since there is an easy workaround for this problem, I'm lowering the severity of this problem.

Carl, please re-raise the severity if you don't agreed.

Hey Kathy,

If you mean on disk, the answer is no.  The WebContent folder does not need to exist at all.  At runtime it does, so they could map whatever folder they wanted to WebContent in their .component file.  Hope that helps.
Mark, please take a look at this bug.

This bug seems to happen when the WEB-INF folder is not in the project. I can only reproduce this by deleting the WEB-INF folder, or intentionally not checking that folder into CVS, which are both unusual scenarios so I don't think this is a problem anymore.

I committed a new dynamic web project to CVS after adding one java file to the src folder. When I checked out this project from CVS and it had the following directory structure:

- Echo
  - src
    + CVS
    - test
      Echo.java
  + build
  - WebContent
    - META-INF
      + CVS
      MANIFEST.MF
    - WEB-INF
      + CVS
      web.xml
  .classpath
  .project
  
Note that the WebContent and WEB-INF folders exist.

I was able to create a bottom up web service from Echo.java without any problems. The WebContent folder is not empty when the project is created, so it will checked into CVS.

If I delete the WEB-INF folder then I get this exception when creating a bottom up webservice. I'm not sure that this is a big problem since a Dynamic Web Project should normally have a WEB-INF folder when the project is checked out from CVS unless it was deleted, or not checked in.
Kathy, just a reminder, the WEB-INF folder does not have to exist on disk or in the repo.  A project just needs to have a mapping in the .component to a "WEB-INF" folder at runtime.
Clearing Target Milestone field and using Whiteboard field to capture desired target: 1.5 RC4.

Created an attachment (id=42263)
patch for org.eclipse.jst.ws.internal.common plugin
The above patch creates the WEB-INF folder if it does not exist on disk.  It seems to solve this problem.

Approved for RC4.

Patch reviewed and committed.  Will release later.

User Impact: If the user tries to create a web service when the web-inf folder is not there (has been deleted or not pulled from CVS) then the web service creation fails with the exception reported in this bug.

Scope: The scope of this fix is small.  Only one method was changed: getWebInfPath in org.eclipse.jst.ws.internal.common.J2EEUtils.  Now this method checks that the path actually exists on disk before it returns, and if not it creates the neccessary folders.
Released to WTP 1.5 RC4 as v200605242132.
I am sorry for the delay.  I have now confirmed this bug has been resolved.
